description: This collection uses primary sources to explore Latin American revolutionary leaders.

affiliation.name: Lexington School District One, South Carolina

hasPart.name: Questions
hasPart.text:
1. Using the [map of colonies](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/901), describe the various geographic features that promoted and/or discouraged communication and unification in Latin America. What do you notice about the geography of cities highlighted on the map and the geography of battle sites?
2. After reading the biographical information about each of the leaders included in this set, draw comparisons between them with regard to their motivation for liberation and independence and their plans for the new nations they fought to free.
3. Read the [excerpt from J.R. Beard’s biography](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/906). What are the major similarities between L’Ouverture and Napoleon Bonaparte? How were these two men different?
4. Look at the [portrait of Simón Bolívar](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/908) and the [image of a statue of Bolívar](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/910). What other figures throughout history have been clad in such a way? What do you think the artist’s intent was when choosing such attire? Look at other portraits in this set and analyze how each of the freedom fighters are depicted.

hasPart.name: Activity
hasPart.text: Ask students to create a two-page spread for a children’s book depicting the “road to liberation” for Latin Americans. Students should include information about the four freedom fighters highlighted in this set: José de San Martin, Simón Bolívar, Toussaint L’Ouverture, and Miguel Hidalgo. Ask students to combine their stories using a road map or timeline suitable for a children’s book.

hasPart.name: Teaching Guide: Exploring Latin American Revolutionaries
Resources
hasPart.text:
1. [The Other Revolution: Haiti 1789-1804](http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/John_Carter_Brown_Library/exhibitions/haitian/index.html), John Carter Brown Library, Brown University.  
2. [The Spanish American Revolutions: Setting the Stage](http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/John_Carter_Brown_Library/exhibitions/spanishsetting/index.html), John Carter Brown Library, Brown University. 
3. “[Enshrined and Oft-Invoked, Simon Bolivar lives on](http://www.npr.org/2013/04/13/176783269/enshrined-and-oft-invoked-simon-bolivar-lives-on),” NPR.

hasPart.name: Overview
hasPart.text: After the United States secured its independence from Great Britain in 1783, a passion for liberty and sovereignty began to spread to other nations in the Americas. The French Revolution, begun in 1789, further promoted ideas of “liberty, equality, and fraternity.” In the eighteenth century, Latin American peoples were burdened by colonial control imposed through high taxes, a very powerful church, oppressive working conditions including slavery. To change these conditions, various leaders began movements that would alter the political and cultural landscape of this region: Toussaint L’Ouverture in Haiti (1791), Miguel Hidalgo in Mexico (1810), José de San Martin in what is now Argentina, Chile, and Peru (1808), and Simón Bolívar in what is now Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador, and Peru (1808). (Although Haiti is quite different from the other revolutionary movements listed in this set, its revolution is a turning point in Latin American history.) With European powers like France and Spain occupied with the Napoleonic wars and their aftermath, Latin American territories began to slip free from colonizers’ control. Only some attempts at independence were fully successful, but seeds sowed by these early revolutions would yield a great harvest in years to come. In this set, students will begin to see how a group of revolutionaries shaped both the map and the mindset of Latin American nations.

name: Latin American Revolutionaries
